title: Jacky Gillott
text:
Jacqueline Anne Gillott (24 September 1939 – 19 September 1980), was an English novelist and broadcaster. She was one of Britain's first woman television reporters.
Life and career.
Born in <a href="Bromley">Bromley</a>, <a href="Kent">Kent</a>, Jacky Gillott attended <a href="University%20College%20London">University College London</a>. She worked as a journalist for a provincial newspaper before starting a television career with <a href="Independent%20Television%20News">Independent Television News</a>. She later presented programmes on the <a href="British%20Broadcasting%20Corporation">BBC</a>, including early editions of the <a href="Film...%20%28TV%20programme%29">Film Show</a>. She also wrote five successful novels between 1968 and 1979.
She was married to the television producer <a href="John%20Percival%20%28TV%20producer%29">John Percival</a>, and they had two sons. They moved to a small farm in <a href="Somerset">Somerset</a> in 1972 to live as near as possible to self-sufficiency; she wrote about their experiences in a book, "Providence Place" (1977).
Death.
In 1980, after suffering from depression and marital troubles, she took her own life at her cottage in <a href="Pitcombe">Pitcombe</a>, Somerset.
After her death, Jacky and John's friend and neighbour <a href="John%20Fowles">John Fowles</a> described her as "a brittle, sexy, faintly raucous persona always", but noted that underneath there was somebody "ugly, confused, uncertain – all that she didn't sound on TV or radio".
Books.
Her journalism included the posthumously published memoir "Twelfth Man", a contribution to <a href="Michael%20Meyer%20%28translator%29">Michael Meyer's</a> <a href="cricket">cricket</a> anthology "Summer Days" (1981), in which she wrote: "I have cricket to thank for the healing knowledge that nothing in this world lacks a comic profile and that it is more pleasurable to laugh in company than it is to laugh alone. Thus armoured, one can overcome the hurt and disappointment of many a thing ..."
